The Secretary of State for India informed the Cahinet that he had shown to Lord CarsonLord Cave1s letter to the Prime Minister inregard to the decision of the Judicial Committeeof the Privy Council in the matter of the IrishCivil Servants. Lord Carson was too farcommitted to certain interests to withdraw hisMotion in the House of Lords that afternoon,even if he had wished to do so. Moreover,there would not be much advantage in a postponement of the Debate, since sooner or later legislation will be necessary and a Debate would have totake place which would cwver the same groundas that involved in Lord Carson1s Motion. he therefore raised for the consideration of theCabinet the question of the line he should take,in regard to which he offered certain suggestionsaccording closely with the conclusion set forthbelow.In the course of the discussion it transpired that Viscount Ealdane and Lord Dunedin,who had been Lord. Cave1 s colleagues on theJudicial Committee of the Privy Council, agreed with Lord. Cave that an error had been made, moreparticularly in regard to an essential date,and. that they were prepared to state this in theHouse of Lords the same afternoon. There wasalso general agreement in the Cabinet that itwas extremely difficult to defend the Government1spolicy except by the admission that the JudicialCommittee had made a mistake. The principal t) 0 9questions at issue therefore, were -(I) whether, having regard to the importanceof maintaining the prestige of theJudicial Committee of the Privy Councilthroughout the British Empire, it wasjustifiable, and if so, desirable, to admit that a mistake had been made;(ii) whether it would be desirable in thecourse of the Debate that Lord Cave'sletter to the Prime Minister shouldbe read to the House of Lords.After considerable discussion, the Cabinet(a) That in all the circumstancesof the case the best course wasto make a frank admission thatthe Judicial Committee had madea mistake, an admission which twoof the Members who had subscribedto the Judgment were themselvesprepared to make;(b) That in view of the willingness of the two Judges to admit themistake it was desirable in justice to the late Lord Cave, as well asin all probability in accordancewith what he himself would have wished, that his concurrence withthe views of his two Judicialcolleagues should be made known.(c) That the Secretary of State forIndia and the Lord Chancellor shouldhave authority to use Lord Cave'sletter to the Prime Minister in -such manner as seemed best, havingregard to the course which the debate might take, and to read it if they thought desirable.(d) That the Secretary of State forIndia should be careful not to commit himself as to the precise form of the legislationvrtaich would have to be intro-duced to rectify the matter.(The Secretary of State for Indiawithdrew from the Cabinet at thispoint in order to prepare a statementtor the House of Lords on thissubject). 9 ft 1ti 4 irjgg JUDICIALCOMMITTEE OPtpflB privy council.(previous reference:Cabinet 13(28), Con-elusion 8.)S. Arising out of the consideration of thequestion referred to in the previous Conclusion,attention was drawn once more to the desirabilityof strengthening the Judicial Committee of the privy Council and bringing down the average ageof its members.The Lord Chancellor informed his colleagues of his intention to give careful consideration 'to the question during the next few months, andin due course, if he thought desirable, to bringproposals before them. 4. The Secretary of State for Foreign affairs recalled that, when the negotiations for theTreaty of Alliance with Egypt had failed, he had warned the Egyptian Government that His Majesty'sGovernment must stand by the Declaration of 1932,and had afterwards insisted that the AssembliesBill, the effect of which would be to paralysethe power of the police forces in Egypt to main-tain order, must not be proceeded with. It was clear that Nahas Pasha, the Egyptian Prime Minis-ter, and his Party found t?a ems elves in difficul-ties as to how to extricate themselves from theposition, A telegram received that morning from lord Lloyd (No. 233, of April 24th) indicated the possibility of a split in the EgyptianCabinet on the subject.Sir Austen Chamberlain proposed to authoriseLord Lloyd, 24 hours before the reconsideration of the Assemblies Bill by the Egyptian Senate,to issue a further warning to the Egyptian PrimeMinister on the lines of the proposals in lord lloyd's telegram. Fo. 250, insisting on hispreventing the Bill from becoming law. If this further warning proved ineffective, Lord Lloydwould be authoi^ised^ within 72 hours of hisNote, to send for ships to Alexandria and. to seize the Customs. This firm, action appearedto Sir Austen Chamberlain essential, as to allow the Bill to pass would be to incur a heavyresponsibility not only towards our own people in Eg^pt but also towards foreigners whoseGovernments we did*not permit themselves to take measures to protect their atibjects.
